entry.title: The 99 Percent Lunch
entry.content:
Our fateful leader Barry is off in NYC today at the 99 Percent Conference. The conference’s tag line is “It’s not about ideas. It’s about making them happen.” So we’re expecting him to come back pretty inspired.

We found some inspiration of our own today. While the boss was away, the entire Hypenotic crew took a Cinco de Mayo road trip to have lunch at Agave y Aguacate in Kensington Market. Turns out Agave y Aguacate is a living case study in how to make ideas happen and get others to relish the experience of sharing someone else’s vision.

I had heard about this great new Mexican “restaurant” from several sources–Edible Toronto,  Ivy Knight and others  I trust. I called up the owner Francisco Alejandri to see if he was open for dinner, since I was considering going there with a friend Friday night. He said he was only open for lunch, so I rounded up the troops and off we went.

One step inside and I realized why my dinner question was so absurd. This wasn’t a restaurant at all (there were no chairs, no tables, not even a stool) it’s a food stall situated among other Latin American food vendors, tucked into a tiny shop on Augusta Street. It’s a postage stamp. Boy, had I pictured it differently.

But that doesn’t mean it was a disappointment. In fact, it was an entirely memorable dining experience.

First there’s the red wall. It sets Agave y Aguacate apart from all of the other vendors that share the space. Their signs are vinyl and the usual standard fare. His just looks amazing. Much of the time I spent waiting for my food to be prepared I spent wondering how the other vendors manage their resentment as the line builds in front of Francisco’s tiny induction stove. Of course the line had a lot to do with the food but that magnificent wall made this spot stand out. And flourishes like this are in no way incidental. The chef knows the red wall is significant because *every single photo *on his facebook page is taken in front of this wall. That wall is partly what gives the restaurant a presence much bigger than its physical size.

In a great article written by Kelly Jones for  Good Food Revolution Francisco commented on the red wall:

I want a place that satisfies all your senses. You know, this is why I did the mural. The aromas of the food, and the way it looks, the way I dress—everything, everything has a repercussion to the dishes that I make.”

Then there’s the food preparation. I’m not going to lie to you, it’s an agonizing wait. As Kelly Jones put it:

You can come and meet Francisco and sample his fare, but be prepared to wait—even if you’re the only person in line. Each plate is made to order—as in, nothing is sliced, diced, minced, or scooped ahead of time.

Initially, there seems to be something incongruous about a food stand where the food is meticulously and oh-so-slowly prepared. The wait is outrageous. Under any other circumstances I’d be incensed. If I was waiting for take out food at some generic joint, I would have left, and made a lot of noise on the way out.

But watching the process made the food well worth waiting for. In fact, watching Francisco cook was a valuable lesson in why it’s essential to have the patience to do things right. Even as the line grew, the Chef kept his cool, never waivering from preparing his food as if it were the first time he’d ever made that particular dish.

The phone is always ringing, the email inbox grows; that’s how business goes. But regardless, it’s essential to do the job right, no matter how busy you get. It’s nice to be reminded of it once in a while. Heck, it’s nice to have deep thoughts while waiting for my lunch.

So, while Barry’s at a conference about turning vision into reality, I’m pretty sure the rest of us here at Hypenotic got an up close view of what it takes to stand true to visionary ideas no matter what. And, while the Tostadas were incredibly good, watching that happen before my eyes was even better.

entry.title: Satisfy your information urges with the Infographic
entry.content:
Undeniably, we now have an expectation for instant satisfaction- if information is not presented to us in a very immediate way, we lose interest-Erin McPhee

The majority of people, myself included, are content hungry and research lazy. We don’t want to take the time to read. At the same time we want to know everything  we could imagine at the speed of light. News worthy and useful content has become increasingly accessible; next on the agenda is making content faster and easier to understand.

So what is the anecdote  to make interesting content quickly digestible? Infographics.  They’re popping up everywhere and on every conceivable topic. This infographic on the right was created to map the social media buzz around the Royal wedding.

The illustration is easy to follow and allows the viewer to quickly absorb the highnotes:

  • Most people chose to use twitter to write about the wedding
  • The Queen was the celebrity that was most written about
  • Social media was consistently sued throughout the entire day
  • The US contributed to more than half of the overall social media buzz on the topic

If I had opened Linkedin to find a long article about social media and the Royal Wedding I would have ignored it. But instead, I got a little info-snack that satisfied my appetite for information about the royal wedding.

This leads me to an important question:

Are we becoming  savvy in our efforts to intake information quickly, or are we simply becoming intellectually lazy?

Erin McPhee, Illustration Student at Sheridan College, and Hypenotic’s newest Graphic Design Intern, says:

“I believe that we exist in a very visceral media environment-  information is often delivered to us in the form of images (we’re seeing more and more infographics in place of, or in conjunction with print/editorial information.) Undeniably, we now have an expectation for instant satisfaction- if information is not presented to us in a very immediate way, we loose interest. In this respect, we’re more impatient. However as long as the work presented by  illustrators, artists and designers respects and appeals to the intelligence of the reader, I would say that it is not an inherently bad thing.”

What do you think?

entry.title: Better Blogging: Lessons from a Dumpling Joint
entry.content:
Have you been to Mother’s Dumplings? It’s an always packed Chinese dumpling, noodle and bun spot in the heart of Toronto’s China Town on Spadina Avenue. They have a very unassuming website, no Twitter presence and a very small following on Facebook. But Mother’s Dumplings taught me a very important lesson about social media.

One of the few elements (besides the dumplings) that Mother’s carried from their former “hole in the wall” digs to their new shiny location is a reverence for customer comments. Their walls were literally plastered with hand scrawled notes and drawings expressing an evangelical love of Mother’s dumplings.

Like many restaurants Mother’s provides comment cards and asks people to fill them in and provides a locked box to drop them in. Swiss Chalet does basically the same thing, nothing original there. So how does Mother’s manage to get so many comments?

I’ll tell you how: They frame them and hang them on the wall.

What does this insight reveal about generating more comments online? I’ve made the connection between Problogger’s post on this subject and the Mother’s Dumpling example.

 

 

 

Invite comments

You can leave it open ended by just having that blank “comments” box at the bottom of the blog post or you can actually ask people for their 2 cents by asking a question at the end of your post. The more you invite comments, the more likely you are to get them. Mother’s takes it one step further than Swiss Chalet by getting you to think about your comments while you’re still munching your smashed cucumber salad (which is divine by the way). ** **

Interact with comments left/Reward Comments

** *If someone takes the time to comment on your blog post you should take the time to respond. The most important thing this does, according to ProBlogger, is demonstrate that your comments section is “an active place that you as the blogger value.” In the case of Mother’s, I can’t think of a much better way of demonstrating appreciation for customer comments than framing and mounting them on the wall for all to see. * **

Be Humble

** **This is an important one, and something that I hadn’t considered. If you seem like a know-it-all, then why would anyone bother to comment? If people fear they’ll be shut down it’s even more likely that they’ll stay silent. It’s a fine balance between positioning oneself as a leader and closing the door to interactivity–which is at the heart of social media. When Mother’s invites concerns or compliments you get the feeling that they really want to know how they can be better. Check out this blurb from their otherwise content light website:

Ours is a cozy, welcoming café. If Zhen seems tired some days, it  is because she cooks her heart to make dumplings as good as her mother makes them.

What brings comments to your website? I’d love to hear what’s worked for you.

entry.title: Don’t Let The Muffin Top be the New Mullet
entry.content:
A shopping expedition to Buffalo drew my attention to the latest phenomenon in women’s fashion–the muffin top has come out of the closet.

In a department store, two very mainstream brands of women’s pants, namely Levis and Lee were selling clothes that claim to “hide your muffin top.” But of course, as the label says, “Ssssh…it’s our little secret.”

Don’t know what a muffin top is? Well, thankfully the Oxford Dictionary has included it in its most recent edition, defining it as, “a protuberance of flesh above the waistband of a tight pair of trousers.”

At the same time that it’s out in the open, the muffin top has become a source of shame. It’s kind of like the new mullet. Whole websites like Muffinhuntin exist solely to shine a spotlight on women’s abdominal “protuberances.”

Let’s face it, most women with muffin tops are moms. A flabby belly is one of the markers of having bore children. This muffin top hating is a slap in the face to moms who not only bear the responsibility of childbirth but its long lasting effects on their stomachs.

Even though we think of girdles as a vestige from an oppressive past, they were a whole lot more comfy than their more ‘modern’ successor Spanxs. Check out this Ode to Girdles in which the writer praises “the miraculous smoothing effect of what I fondly call My Garments.”

I think it’s time to reclaim the muffin top or the girdle. It’s one or the other people. If you’re inclined to embrace girdle-dom there are plenty out there. Check out ebay or sites like Little Pink Dress.

And, if you’re more inclined to wear your muffin top like a battle wound, check out this great video parody of Lady Gaga’s Poker Face called Muffin Top with great lyrics including: “Before these kids my bod was the bomb. Now I take my top off and I look like my mom.”

Which choice do you prefer? I’m on the fence on this one.

entry.title: Are you Ooey Gooey at the Centre?
entry.content:
We could all learn a lesson from chocolate-bar makers–what you put at the centre matters most.

The centre is where your mission lives.

A tactic is not a mission (“we’re an advocate” “we’re a festival” “we sell groceries”). If you put a tactic at the centre then you forget to ask why anyone else should care what you’re doing.  You need to take stock and consider why you run a festival or sell groceries, and why does it matter to people other than the few who care because they work for you or they love you (like your mom).

If you put the ooey gooey goodness at the core then you attract the right kind of people who dig your particular flavour, texture and ingredients. Then you’re not in the chocolate bar business, and you can do things beyond make chocolate bars–as long as the other tactics you choose to do connect back to what’s at the core.

If Hershey’s was really smart, York Peppermint Patty would be in the travel business. It’s all about that “sensation” right?

entry.title: Garden Tourism Conference: What We Learned
entry.content:
Gardening tourism. When I told people that I was going to a Gardening Tourism Conference, their reaction was always the same “Gardening Tourism. What’s that?” I had an inkling, but I wasn’t sure myself.

Truth is I didn’t think of myself as a gardening tourist. But the conference reminded me of all of the garden experience I’ve engaged in–both locally and when travelling. I go to High Park when the cherry blossoms are in bloom; I toured orchid growing areas in Thailand; And my kids and I visit Butterfly World in Del Ray Florida when we head to see my folks every winter.

So, while gardens might seem rather niche, they are a real draw. The Travel Activities and Motivation Survey found that visits to gardens are one of the top things affluent seniors want to see when they travel. But, it’s not just seniors visiting gardens. And, gardens are engaging in some very innovative programming to get people to visit regularly.

One of the real appeals of gardens is that they get you out of “buying stuff” mode that so often happens on vacation (even though this may not be what gardening sites with gift shops want to hear) and the money I am spending (on entry fee) is on a social good–more gardens means more beauty, cleaner air, protection of species, etc. It’s a win/win. It’s an authentic experience that is educational and soul enriching.

The conference speakers included a number of luminaries in the field including Pascal Garbe, Director of the European Gardens & Tourism conference, Alan Jolliffe from Christchurch New Zealand, Karen Daubmann from New York Botanical Garden in New York, and our own Barry Martin who presented how the power of social media can be used to increase and broaden the market for garden tourism.

It was an interesting event, so we thought we’d share some of our learnings with you

entry.title: Community Building from the core: Wiggly Wigglers
entry.content:
I think the way people buy, is to get them to be enthusiastic. I’ve always thought, people don’t buy on price. They buy on whether or not they care about what you are doing. So, all I have to do is to make you care and hopefully we will get your business! I don’t think people care about advertising anymore

A Wiggly Mission

Answer these questions for me:

  • Why don’t you have a worm composter?
  • Why don’t you have tomatoes growing in your backyard in summer?
  • Why haven’t you started growing plants from seed?

To my mind, for those who are inclined there’s only one answer; because it all seems like more than you can manage–either it’s “too complicated” or takes “too much time.” In life’s cost/benefit analysis, the benefits simply aren’t outweighing the costs.

Wiggly Wigglers, a Natural Gardening Company based in rural Herefordshire, UK has you all figured out. Their tagline “The Good Life, Made Easy ” sums up the company’s twofold mission to:

  • Demonstrate that a life in harmony with nature is “the good life”–well worth the time and effort
  • Make accessing this “good life” manageable for anyone

The way they do this is by creating a passionate ‘community of interest’ that brings together the people who are taking steps (one step or one hundred and eleven steps) toward living in harmony with nature–the good life. These people may be environmentalists, gardeners, parents with kids, urban folks with rural dreams, etc. But, together they form a community of interest who want to improve their relationship to the earth and nature.

Manifesting their mission

Create educational resources

** **The company’s leaders Heather Gorringe and Farmer Phil provide teaching tools to help people figure out what to do with a worm composter, a birdfeeder or how to plant from seed. Sure that means more composters, birdfeeders or seeds are sold, but their passion for expanding the movement comes first.Wiggly Wigglers engages this community of interest in several ways, all of which are clear manifestations of their core mission.

Check out this video (with over 10,000 views!) demonstrating how to get started with a basic worm composter. It’s not just the content to take note of, it’s the tone.

Heather is dressed in her regular, everyday clothes. No hair, no makeup. And there’s a general sense of good-humor happening as they talk about worm composting.  This is not Martha Stewart with an air of refinement and a layer of distance. These are just plain ‘ol people like you and me.

In fact, they have an entire Wiggly Cinema chock-a-block with educational videos that help build one’s natural gardening skills.

Demonstrate Rural Cred

You’ve heard of street cred, right? Well this Heather Gorringe and Farmer Phil are oozing rural cred. Their weekly  “Wiggly Podcasts” are on serious topics related to rural life–topics that are not directly related to their business–like cattle disease and neglected woodlands.

The podcasts demonstrate Wiggly Wigglers’ deep commitment to and knowledge of rural life. After listening to one, you can have no doubt that these folks are the real deal.

Building Community

Wiggly Wigglers is all about community. As they say on their About Us page:

“One of the best things about buying Wiggly is that you become part of the growing Wiggly Community.”

In other words, when you marry the Wiggly Wigglers, the whole Wiggly family shows up and parks their Winnebago in your backyard.

That’s because Wiggly Wigglers is on a mission to celebrate a particular approach to the “good life.” Importantly, this is not Wiggly Wigglers grandstanding their idea–it’s about creating a forum for the community to collectively showcase how grand the good life can be. Wiggly Wigglers just provides the framework for them to do it.

Check out this Facebook discussion page where the site moderators bounce questions out to the community rather than simply answering them. This is Wiggly Wigglers’ style.

Beyond education, the community is a place for people to share their pride in what they’re doing–to get gold stars for taking one step further down the path to natural living.  Several wall posts are simply people declaring how much they love the products they’ve ordered.

And check out the kinds of pictures people have posted of their Wiggly Wiggler stuff–from 1/2 frozen worms to innovative use for packaging. Owner Heather Gorringe is just one member of a community that is flourishing around a shared passion for natural gardening.

Between the educational and celebratory dimensions of their mission, Wiggly Wigglers has stripped away all of the barriers to engagement. Suddenly it’s well worth the time and effort required to take the steps to live in harmony with nature.

Can you think of other brands so clearly living their mission?

entry.title: Twitter help is here: DontPinMyStream
entry.content:
The “Don’t P in my Stream” project is a public service intended to:

  • Help twitter newbies jump to the head of the class
  • Preserve the twitter ecosystem
  • Be useful to seasoned users

More than a little inspired by Merlin Mann’s ThanksNo project from a few years ago that was a boon in the early days of email overload, if the project can be a fraction as useful as ThanksNo has been, it will be worth it. Hell, if it gets used at all we’ll be impressed.

The truth is we’ve met clients, employees, partners and peers on twitter and we love it. It’s been an amazing journey from our first tepid tweets, wrestling our way up the learning curve of a mountain thats shape is evolving  underneath us to a resource we’re quite literally addicted to.

On the page, we listed a few twitter basics to avoid like:

  • Tweeting inanity (in an era of info-overload, ‘self-filtering’ is essential)
  • Promoting your company/organization/client (This is communications dept, not sales)
  • Telling us where you are or what you’re doing instead of why it matters (be useful please)
  • #hashtagging the #hell out of #the #tweet (you’re fostering # blindness)
  • Tweeting too many times in a short period (clogs up our stream w/your avatar)

But there are invariably more out there like:

  • Mindless retweets (Without reading the link)
  • Group #FFs (It’s generally better to say something informative about an individual)
  • Group #FF Retweets (that’s a bit lazy, no?)
  • Personal conversations in public (Overdoing it comes across as a bit needy, don’t you think?)

So do feel free to add your pet peeve in the comments or via twitter.

And conversely, do feel free to make a case for a particular behaviour if you’re so inclined.

So, if you want to politely suggest that someone you follow should avoid certain twitter behaviours, send them to this handy page, and let them know you care enough to tell them like it is.

entry.title: Here I am at Camp Ikea….
entry.content:
IKEA has always been a very family friendly store. Amenities from parent parking spots to drop-off childcare centers (Småland) to stellar bathrooms with baby change stations put them in a category above all others.

During March Break IKEA is hosting a camp called “Camp IKEA” featuring face-painting, firemen, tree planting and more. It has inspired me to write a little song about what it must be like to be a kid at Camp IKEA.”

All good so far.

But for me, the name Camp IKEA takes this a bit too far. Even though all of the activities offered at IKEA during March Break require parent supervision, the name ‘Camp IKEA’ is pushing some buttons and making me feel cynical.

It’s reminding me March Break is one of the few times that kids are out of school and available to hang out with their friends and their folks and have fun.  When you say ‘camp’ I think of a place that is child-centered, not a grownup place that manages to keep kids amused while parents shop.<!--more-->

Frankly, the words “Camp” and “IKEA” together make it seem pathetic that parents would schlep their kids to IKEA during this particular week. In short, it’s making me more cynical than I want to be about IKEA’s intentions.

IKEA wants me to think nice, Swedish thoughts about equality, and love and goodness. I think a name like Smalstuff, or Smalfun would make IKEA seem like less of a shopping enabler and more like a helpful friend.

Happy March Break.

entry.title: Lunch Money Day
entry.content:
I always thought Second Harvest’s Lunch Money Day was a great idea. It’s one of those great fundraising ideas the involve asking folks to do something they would normally do–but to do it differently for a great cause.

Fact is, the average person in Toronto spends at least $5 on lunch every day. For most of us it’s a convenience we take for granted. So, for one day we manage without the convenience of a bought lunch and divert resources to Toronto’s hungry. If you think brown bagging it is inconvenient, just think about eating baked potatoes for two weeks. That’s just one story out of the just released Recession Relief Coalition report.

So, on Lunch Money day myself and my companion Agata hit the subway platform  to round up some fundraising dollars and drum up some awareness. I was there with several other eager volunteers who woke up much too early to make a difference. Here’s a short video about our experience that day.

entry.title: Podcamp Toronto 2011: My biggest lesson
entry.content:
On Saturday, the first day of Podcamp Toronto 201 1, Lionel, our Lead digital designer/dev sent me about 20 emails from the sessions he was in. Not about what people were saying, but about what his brain was saying, catalysed by what he was hearing.

I read his notes from my couch, where I was working on a proposal (not even with my family!). Work is more important than inspiration right? Well, I shouldn’t put it that way. I’m inspired daily by things I read, people I work with and the flashes of insight that come to me every time I walk to/from work or to the bathroom (everyone walks out of our bathrooms with an idea. Try it!) daily.

But I rarely go to conferences with my peers.  I’ve been attending and speaking at conferences focussed on my client’s issues. Since we have many clients in the food and social justice space, this can be yummy and rewarding. But in the few hours I caught today, I:

  • Heard 5 dynamic women lay out the trials of a bringing  a strategic approach to big brand marketing in a digital era as well as their thoughts on the opportunities ahead of us (worth a whole post in and of itself)  in THE KICK-ASS WOMEN OF NEW & SOCIAL MEDIA
  • Caught a state of the union update on what big companies like Edelman are thinking about measurement (ditto the last brackets, maybe two posts) from Rob Clark, one of the few folks you’ll meet with the word ‘measurement’ in his job title
  • Connected with about 2o smart, interesting folks I intend to keep up with, and re-connected with 5 I haven’t seen in a while
  • Picked up 15 new twitter followers
  • Learned that for folks in a virtual vacuum, we’re on top of our shit
  • Enjoyed being in rooms full of people who were interested in tactics, but knew they were in service to a strategy
  • Connected with an old acquaintance who happens to need a mobile app with features we’ve been testing
  • Connected with a community of interest

It took me over an hour (with a stop at Porchetta), but I walked the whole way home just to keep the wheels turning.

There are several conferences who’s douche-factor I can still taste when I think about them, so the jury’s still out on how much energy I can devote to communing with the communications industry at large. But the experience I had today made it pretty clear that there’s plenty of value in bouncing ideas off people facing the same challenges you are.

It’s nice to spend a day when you’re not expected to have all the answers.

Thanks, Podcamp.

entry.title: Content is King…again
entry.content:
With the announcement today of Google’s major algorithmic change to its search engine we are, once again, back in the land where good content reigns supreme.  Like weeds in your garden, websites that have something useful to say and a story to tell have been suffering in page rank to the others that stuff, steal and copy content in order to “game” the system in the hopes of getting to that all elusive #1 Google search result.

As one commenter on Mashable says, Bring it on, my site is ready

It’s simple. It doesn’t matter if you’re writing content for a social media campaign, a blog post, a newsletter or website, if it ain’t quality don’t write it. If one of the worlds biggest companies is touting and investing in the importance of quality content, that should say something. Content is still King. If you don’t know how to be King, check out copyblogger or 20 tips on how to write for the web to get you started.

If Google gets it right, the ubiquitous “we” will spend less time searching and more time consuming quality.  It’s about time.

entry.title: I choose choice
entry.content:
It was Friday night and I was on my way home from a meeting with my friend Eugene, an extremely talented violin player better known as Dr. Draw. Amongst the things we discussed, we talked about the possibility of him playing for a Beads for Beds event; the organization I’m directing.

I entered Ossington station and was overwhelmed by a group of teenagers on the opposite platform that were yelling at each other, obviously intoxicated. A man on a long black coat shifted a Rubik’s cube in his hands at a speed that fascinated me and it gave me the feeling that some invisible force was directing the whole scene. People’s public behavior changes on Friday nights and me, I was the silent and oblivious participant of many stories.

Amongst the over-excited voices of intoxicated youth, I sat and observed the string of ads above the passenger’s heads. All of a sudden I became disenchanted, the feeling of oblivion was gone. One after the other, the signs seemed to be telling me what to do. “Build your own box” the ad for Taco Bell read. Right next to it, “Share the good” -Foodland Ontario. “Look no further” -French Education board. “Transfer some money at your next transfer” -RBC. “Protect yourself from the flu” -Government of Canada- Okey, at least they care about my health, right?. “Turn yous passion into a career” -Ontario Government. “Change your life” -some book of self-help. And finally, the BIG punch: “Do you need a psychiatrist?”

So yes, you are crazy. You are also fat, ignorant, unhealthy and have no idea what to do with your life.  So let us tell you what to eat, what to wear, what to smell like and what to do with your time. I looked at the ads with perplexity, realizing how many subliminal messages we are being force-fed daily. I wonder if I’m the only one noticing that all these ads have one thing in common: they all start with a verb. A verb! What does that mean? Advertisement today does not work as suggestions, they are commandments; at least so it seems…

On the bus from Dufferin to King the same scenario. One thing was different though. Amongst all the ads telling me what to do, one stood out from the crowd; it was from Centennial College. “What did you want to be? Over 250 programs to help you become what and who you always wanted to be” It was a reminder that we still have a choice…

Here is a video on The Command Economy. Humor is the key…

entry.title: Fuck The Draft!
entry.content:
In his book Trust Agents, Chris Brogan says “Building an army, especially a loosely-joined and flexible group of people from many disciplines, is the key to being an advanced trust agent.”

Of course everyone wants to build an army–a mass of followers from all walks of life. But the critical question is when you start building your army. You don’t want to start asking folks to join you when you need something from them. That’s called conscription and it’s not generally popular. Social networking platforms don’t allow for conscription–so folks often resort to tactics like guilt, pleading and invoking a sense of duty.

However, being useful and relevant–giving not taking–is key to enlist people in a cause that is bigger than yourself; your event, your cause, your services, and whatever else you’re trying to sell.

Two authors, Rebecca Skloot and James Beckerman, both with wildly successful books, started sharing and building communities of interest long before they ever had books to sell.

Skloot’s ten year journey to write her book The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks was thoughtfully chronicled by the author who let her community in on what she was was discovering while getting to know Henrietta Lacks, the impoverished African American woman whose HeLa cells transformed modern medicine. Skloot turned the process inside out and engaged her readers long before there was ever a book. She talked about a broad range of issues on science and ethics–the core area of exploration in her book. Today she has over eleven thousand followers on Twitter not to mention a best selling book that has been optioned as an HBO film by Oprah Winfrey.

Another writer that I’ve been watching for sometime is Portland Cardiologist James Beckerman who just launched his book The Flex Diet. Just yesterday Canadian doctor  and blogger  Yoni Freedhoff reviewed the book, calling Beckerman “a socially networked cardiologist.” The point is, long before there was a book, Beckerman was sharing useful tips, tools and resources that helped people lose weight. Twitter was the perfect medium for sharing small tips on weight management, which is the premise of the Flex Diet.  Today Beckerman has written over 2,700 tweets and has over a thousand followers. So when his book finally launched, lots of folks were already fans of his approach to weight management.

The point is this; Don’t start your social networking journey when you are ready to ask people to do something for you. Don’t start making friends so you have people to invite to your birthday party.  People who like you want to celebrate your achievements–but they need to know you first. So, what can you share that would help people get engaged in the mission you’re on long before you have anything to ask of them? What ‘bits’ of your journey would be useful and relevant to others? The time to get started is now.

entry.title: Modern times
entry.content:
Researching advertising I came across a website listing the top vintage ads that can make one’s jaw drop in disbelief. The images are worth a million words.

I wonder which of today’s ads people will consider sexist, racist, or inappropriate 50 years from now. Maybe they’ll even come up with new categories all together, like “too humane” or “AI-cist” (discrimination against Artificial Intelligence)

Speaking of A.I. … The technological advancements of the current era are far beyond extraordinary. One of the latest developments in Artificial Intelligence is a computer called Watson, developed by IBM to compete on Jeopardy.

“Watson is powered by 10 racks of IBM servers running the Linux operating system. It’s not connected to the internet but has digested encyclopedias, dictionaries, books, news, movie scripts and more.” (source: http://www.cbc.ca/technology/story/2011/01/14/computer-jeopardy.html#ixzz1EFAjbG1w)

During its first public appearance in Jeopardy, Watson was put to the test against the two game-show’s champions, where he proved that to err is to be non-human…

entry.title: A formal introduction…
entry.content:
Hello everyone!

On this sunny Tuesday morning I’d like for you to help me welcome the latest addition to Hypenotic… myself! Yes, me, Agata. I’m super excited to become part of such wonderful team of creative people who are bursting with ideas, amazing energy and the drive to have a positive impact on the community through meaningful marketing. So, let’s get down to business.

My name is Agata Ivanna Pogorelsky and I was born and raised in Buenos Aires, Argentina. At age 18 -now you want to know how old I am, right?- I moved to Canada, landing in the coldest place I could have ever imagined: Winnipeg. After a year at University of Manitoba, in the Fine Arts program, I moved to Toronto to pursue my acting a career. Ryerson Theater School was a wonderful experience but the language barrier was too big at the time to continue three more years of studies. In 2006, I dropped out of the program and got accepted into the School of Image Arts, which gave me enough flexibility to experiment, play and learn about all the things that excite me, such as photography, video editing, graphic arts and of course, performance.

My work experience is as broad as Winnipeg’s annual thermal amplitude: I have waited tables, administered offices, driven trucks, filmed and edited music videos for local bands and fashion shows, cleaned houses, animated typography for multi-media theater plays, photographed events as a free-lancer-for-free, taught Spanish, etc, etc, etc; you get my point. I’m extremely delighted to embark on a journey as part of Hypenotic’s staff, where I will be able -and encouraged- to combine my various skills and talents working for clients that are doing things that matter to people. Talk about meaningful marketing, eh?

So, how about I give you a little something and introduce you to my alter-ego Fatima Popolopulis? Turn your speakers on and embrace yourself as you join me on a journey to the depths of the Giraffe Center in Nairobi, Kenya. Karibu!

entry.title: How to hire someone to tweet for you
entry.content:
Let me start by saying that having someone tweet for you is almost never a good idea. Kenneth Cole can tell you more about the dangers. So can Price Chopper.

In fact, there are only a few situations that make a ghost-tweeter a good fit.

  1. The person in question is identified as a separate entity, brings you credibility,  and is responsible for community management–that is, they’re hired to implement a communications strategy that partly manifests on  twitter. An example here is Ivy Knight’s work on Fiesta Farms or Jodi’s work for Ontario’s Own. They each do a lot more than tweet. And it’s never about themselves unless they believe the info useful.
  2. It’s your corporate account, you have multiple voices–but even then they should be identifiable somewhere, in a blog post, etc
  3. You’re a trouble maker like Guy Kawasaki and gaming the system while you can.
  4. It’s promotional–Sonya here just mentioned a tattoo parlour that has a guest tweeter for a week. Fun stuff.
  5. I’m open to more, do share.

When is it a particularly bad idea?

When you hire some random self-styled social media guru without a communications strategy, a metrics tracking plan, or check-ins to assess the influence of their work. You can tell these people because they call themselves experts (if they see the word ‘guru’, please throw something wet at them).

Social media marketing is new. We’re really five years into developing pragmatic approaches and measuring the right performance indicators. We have a leg up from the amazing work done in the Search Engine Optimization universe, but that space evolves quickly as well. And frankly, the world of websites is also being affected by expectations people develop from their experiences on social platforms and mobile devices.

Problems range from wasting your money on a hamster wheel you’re paying someone else to get fit on to turning people off with inanity. It’s honestly mind-blowing in an era where a quick search will help you avoid the most established pitfalls that these amount of inanity on twitter persists. These people are dropping small turds all over the internet and stamping your brand on them. Repulsive? Now you’re getting it.

The barrier to a decent tweet is just SO fucking low. The notion that someone being paid to represent your organization can’t come up with more than an encouragement to buy your product is an offense that paints all marketers. We’ve just got the twitter canard about “doing your laundry” or what people ate for dinner” in the rear view mirror and these ‘pros’ show up and drop a load on the windshield.

I’m uncomfortable calling out local brands on this (though I might start soon), this is after all, supposed to be instructive. So here’s what to do about it.

  1. Only talk to prospective representers who’s work you know and like.
  2. If you don’t know anyone and don’t know the space well enough to assess, get a referral from someone who does.
  3. Make sure they get what you stand for. If an honest self-assessment suggests this knowledge must be developed, hire someone who can help you with it (If you’re doing something that doesn’t suck, try us).
  4. Learn how to create a useful presence on twitter, from your profile image and bio to who you should be connecting with on what topics.
  5. Help other people. It’s a community. You become popular by being useful. The more useful you are to more influential people, the better you’re doing.
  6. Define specifically who you’d like to be building relationships with and why.
  7. Define ways to learn from and iterate on your attempts.

If your designated tweeter isn’t doing this strategically, they’re polluting the twitter stream of those too lazy to unfollow them with irrelevance. It would be great if your brand could become part of the solution instead of the problem. Hell that’s a good strategy right there–call it meaningful marketing.

Do feel free to fire back. This rant is over.

entry.title: A Funny Thing Happened At Social Media Week
entry.content:
I went to a Social Media Week event at J.Walter Thompson called Social for Social Good. It was basically on how the power of social change ideas is being accelerated by social media tools.

A not-so-great talk was topped off with an awkward conversation at the end of the event. Please, indulge me because I think it exemplifies what happens when old thinking crashes headlong into new ideas.

Pretty skinny blonde advertising type working the event approaches. She asks “did you like it?”– meaning did I like the event.

“Yeah, it was good” I say, reaching for a morsel of fresh fruit. It wasn’t very good. But I don’t want to talk about it. Not now and not with her.

She asks “Do you* have *Twitter?” The way she asked tipped me off that this was not going to end well. I would ask someone “Do you Tweet?” not “Do you have Twitter?” Sorry, I’m being a snob but it didn’t sound right.

“Yes, I have Twitter” I say back.

“You should Tweet.” She says. And I know exactly what she means. She wants me to Tweet about how great the event was. So she’s being assertive and encouraging me to do just that. She’s being an advertising type.

I play dumb on purpose replying “I DO Tweet”

She looks confused [pause] “You should Tweet that you liked it”

I guess she didn’t realize that if the experience shareworthy, I would share it. It’s Social Media Week for goodness sakes. Every person in the room had some kind of device in their hand. You don’t need to ask me to Tweet.

In fact, it’s kinda like asking someone to make out with you after a date. Either you do or you don’t. But you don’t ask.

Needless to say me and my grapes moved on from JWT. I was relieved to find some fresh air on the other side of the door on a cold February day.

And there you have it. My taste of Social Media Week 2011.

entry.title: Comedy is Tragedy + Time…. and Twitter
entry.content:
I did it. Last night I got up on stage and read at Grownups Read Things they Wrote as Kids. I read some poetry I wrote in grade nine about a boy, love, drugs, zits–you name it. Yes, in a narcissistic way, I just want to share it with you because I did something that was a bit outside my comfort zone and I like that.

But, I also want to reflect on the question you might be asking yourself “why (the hell) did I want to read something I wrote in grade 9?”

In fact, I want reflect on why the 11 other people who read last night jumped on stage to read stuff. On a bigger scale, I want to consider why Dan Misener’s project has been so successful that last night was the 10th anniversary of the event.<!--more-->

I think there’s a clue to all of this in Dan’s own description of how the whole thing got started. Apparently he was at his girlfriend’s house for Christmas when the two stumbled on her old diary. They spent the day reading out loud to one another and discovered:

`This is really funny, reading this stuff out loud to each other. I bet other people are in the exact same boat. I bet a lot of other people have this kind of stuff lying around. And wouldn’t it be fun to get together with a bunch of them and do exactly this?’”

When I was searching for the right stuff to read, I didn’t think the poems I selected were funny at all. In fact, I thought they were tragic. When I was listening to other people’s readings, I thought, “theirs are funny, but mine’s not funny.” But, it turns out my poems were funny too.  As you watch the video, pay attention to where the laughter erupts. It’s worth noting.

The question around why people like to share stuff like this is not unlike understanding the psychology of using social media platforms like Twitter.

Some pop-psychology writers like those who are published in Psychology Today have theorized that it’s all about our need to connect with community. A community that has become more and more inaccessible since the Industrial Revolution.

Others like David Lewis, a cognitive psychologist in the UK, claim that it’s all about existentialism:

“Using Twitter suggests a level of insecurity whereby, unless people recognize you, you cease to exist. It may stave off insecurity in the short term, but it won’t cure it.”

As I reflect on the experience of sharing something awkward and painful, I’m reminded of some of my more painful Tweets. I can remember the hellish parenting moment I was having when I Tweeted,

“These kids could lead a person to Nicorette.”

The tragedy of my parenting situation only became funny when I said it out loud–mostly to strangers out there in the Twitter-verse.

At their best, narcissistic Tweets aren’t much different than reading grade 9 poetry to an audience of grownups. Twitter provides a reflective distance that allows one to step outside of a given moment and therefore have a different reaction to one’s circumstances. Maybe that’s one reason why Twitter’s so big among the mommy crowd.

After all, as the queen of comedy Carole Burnett once said, “Comedy is tragedy plus time.” To that I would add, “Comedy is Tragedy plus Twitter.”

entry.title: Selling Chicago + Having Fun Doing It
entry.content:
This Chicago marketing associate got it right. People don’t want to communicate with nameless, faceless brands. Don’t worry about ‘polish’ and don’t be too sales-y. Truth is, you’ll be more successful if you’re just yourself.

“It was important to show a real person and have a certain kind of genuineness in my tweets,” Lucente says. “You can’t get away with having your tweets go through an approval process. People can see right through that. Sometimes I’m funny, sometimes I’m nerdy, sometimes I’m boring, sometimes I’m super-architectural, and sometimes I’m super-Chicago.”

entry.title: The essence of Social Media Strategy by Gary Vaynerchuck
entry.content:
In a great article in Inc. Magazine, Gary Vaynerchuck, the passionate voice and face of Wine Library TV  lets us in on his day.

He’s clearly addicted to social media, which is a topic for another discussion, but he drops a strategic nugget that can’t be overstated.

It’s one of the insights that will help you separate the exploding ranks of folks billing themselves as social media experts just because they spend time on Twitter, Facebook and Foursquare from those who can help you achieve measurable,  sustainable returns that tie back to your business goals.

Some people think I’m a huckster, but with the show, my intent isn’t to sell our wine. It’s to educate people about wine. There’s a big difference. Too many companies think they want to do a video blog to sell merchandise, but if you turn your site into QVC, you lose. I have an audience that trusts me. It’s about building a global brand—not selling four more bottles of Pinot Grigio.

via The Way I Work: Gary Vaynerchuk.

Wine Library sells wine by day. At the store. That’s not what their marketing does. Their marketing helps people learn more about wine. Gary Vaynerchuck is on a mission to make wine more accessible. To unravel the layers of pompous, posturing jargon and to put down the positioning that makes most people uncomfortable buying wine.  Or used to.

It’s a win/win/win:

  • He gains credibility–a critical asset online, where trust–not cash, is king.
  • The audiences who enjoy his material get free insight shared by a passionate leader.
  • The entire wine industry benefits from the buyers Gary is developing.

A: That’s what we call Meaningful Marketing.

B: What can you credibly and passionately be helping people take part in?

entry.title: Just Write It: Sage Advice from Chris Brogan
entry.content:
I found this from Chris Brogan in my inbox this morning. His newsletter is great. And, if this doesn’t motivate you to blog more often (or at all) I don’t know what will.

Perfect Kills Published

The best sentences don’t sell books (or magazines or whatever). A string of reasonably not bad sentences with useful and engaging information sells books. My books are NOT the best-written books out there on their topic. They’re well-marketed books that I put some soul and heart into. Is every sentence just so? Not even a little bit. But am I a New York Times bestselling author? Oh yes I am. Because I published.

That’s the only difference between where a lot of writers are and where I am: I published.

How? I write. I write all the time. I’m writing this at Walt Disney World, when I should be riding on the Tower of Terror or something. Yes, I do take time to stop and smell the roses, but I don’t neglect my duties. It’s part of what I do. Write. Get writing. Stop making excuses, and don’t look back.

Your successful writing future awaits. Just get publishing.

entry.title: Your Unkempt Assets and Other Lessons
entry.content:
This morning, with one eye open sipping espresso, I found this in my “My Daily Deal” from Living Social in my inbox. Living Social is one of the many websites offering “deeply discounted” deals at local businesses.  This “Daily Deal” was for a discounted Brazilian wax.

I would like to ask the women readers if this description of your vaginal area (That’s right I said vaginal area. And I can say vagina too!) sounds accurate.

“Diamonds may be a girl’s best friend, but when they’re in the rough they can be prickly to the touch — just like your unkempt assets. Here’s a pearl of wisdom: when you snag today’s edge-smoothing Brazilian wax from La Perla Salon & Spa for $25 (regularly $60), you’ll be as happy as a clam. Enjoy a complimentary cappuccino or mineral water while you wait for your appointment; then treat your treasure to this stubble-removing service, selecting either hard or soft wax. Located near Eaton Centre, this lux downtown spa and its team of talented technicians will have you cleaned and polished faster than you can compress a karat’s worth of carbon.”

First of all, how many vagina metaphors can there be in one single ad? Apparently my vagina is a diamond. An unkempt asset. A clam. A treasure.

I’d like to remind La Perla Salon and Spa of the following tenet; “Know Your Audience” is rule #1 of content creation.

Let’s try and get inside the mind of a woman who wants a Brazilian wax, shall we?

How do women who get Brazilian waxes think about their bodies? What is the trigger motivating them to remove all of their pubic hair? For the sake of transparency I’ll say I’ve always found the practice to seem rooted in sexism. But that’s a conversation for another day, and for the purposes of this post, really besides the point.

The question is, what does the Brazilian “do” for the woman who gets one? Because it must do something in order for her to endure this rather unpleasant process.

Consider the following possible options:

  • It makes her feel ‘together’ like a manicure or a haircut. It makes her feel like she’s on her game.
  • It makes her feel pretty, sexy, attractive for herself.
  • Same as above for her partner who she aims to please.
  • It enhances her sex life.

No matter which insight you think is the right one, in the mind of the ‘waxee’ there’s a pay-off for getting a Brazilian. It makes her feel good and somehow empowered.

On the other hand, there is nothing empowering about referring to a woman’s vagina as a “diamond in the rough” or her “unkempt asset.” in fact, it makes her body seem like something solely to be consumed by others. Not to mention the fact that if a woman views her vagina as a treasure, it doesn’t become disgusting the moment it’s less than hairless.

Now, let’s look at a great ad that takes on one of these insights–that it makes women feel more “together” and more attractive to be waxed. The ad avoids being ‘judgey’ like the Brazilian copy does–it says having a neat bikini line is you, but better. And it makes a point of embracing all possible options in the self-grooming category.

Have a peek.

entry.title: Getting Dominos. Who Has the Last Laugh?
entry.content:
The film Food Inc. opens by dispelling the myth that grocery food comes from the idillic looking farms we often see on their packages. To the sounds of eerie music, a voice over says “Even though it looks like a tomato, it’s a notional *tomato. It’s the *idea of a tomato.”

The film is deadly serious about a serious issue. Food Inc.’s focus is on exposing the secrets that the food industry apparently doesn’t want us to know–like the scary places where our food actually comes from.

Food Inc. and other recent films and books have has been incredibly successful at influencing people’s thinking about where their food comes from.

It also seems to be influencing the way marketers are marketing food.Many big food companies are trying to resist being tarred by this brush. And they’re being pretty creative about it.

Dominos pizza has created an entire campaign called “Behind the Pizza.” Here’s the ad promoting the Behind the Pizza website.

I get that this is all supposed to be funny and absurd. Not to be a buzz kill, but I’m going to take the campaign apart to understand how humour functions in the campaign.

The focus group participants are saying they want to know the source of their food, just like films like Food Inc. taught them.

The people behind Dominoes are initially made to seem highly suspect– driven around in limos with blacked-out windows like under cover agents. This is scary big food.

The iconography is over the top. But, it’s directly addressing a post Food Inc. generation, and telling the folks who worry about food that they’re simply paranoid. They use traditional folksy images of farms and farmers to make light of people’s concerns.

Dominos website Behindthepizza.com uses the same kind of humour. At the top of each page where they invite you to explore a specific ingredient, the small print says  “There is not a Dominos actually on the farm.” Well I guess not…hardy har har.

The best example happens when you click on step 1 of the Spinach icon to view a video called Baby Spinach: The Most Sensitive Vegetable. This video talks about “sensitive” baby spinach that grows under a rainbow. Babies and rainbows? I think I’m going to cry. Apparently the spinach cutting machine is tended to by “warm hearted men and women.”

Listen. I get there’s a joke going on here. But the question is what kind of joke is it, and what’s its intended effect?

I would argue that while it seems like Dominoes is using irony,  they’re actually up to something more sinister.

Ironic statements are designed to “convey a meaning exactly opposite from their literal meaning.” Dominoes makes reference to rainbows and babies when talking about their spinach to be funny, but they still want you to associate their food with quality real food, not junk. Put another way, they don’t want you to think that there’s a scary industrial dimension to their food. Otherwise, why bother making a site like this at all?

The flavour of their humour is more like Hyperbole. Unlike irony,  hyperbole is meant to “to evoke strong feelings or to create a strong impression” even though it’s not to be taken literally. So, when you say  “The bag weighed a ton” you’re still trying to convey that the bag is heavy. Just not as heavy as a ton.

Dominoes is going over the top about their spinach and mushrooms and tomatoes  and the farmers who make them to tell everyone who cares about food to take a deep breath and chill out.

But the big reason Dominoes uses hyperbole is to make fun of people who worry about farms as factories. They make it seem like what Food Inc. was saying made big food so scary was that they rely on big machines.

Dude, come on. Food Inc. was pointing to foods as factories based on them producing processed “notional food” it wasn’t about farms using big heavy machinery.

Dominoes is deliberately twisting the idea of factory farming to discredit Food Inc. and other exposés that reveal the dark underbelly of big food.

I feel like I’m teaching a semiotics class or something. Please pardon me for going all academic on you. But this is what it takes to dissect the layers going on in something as simple as a g-damned pizza campaign.

This food fight is turning into very serious business. And don’t kid yourself, the stakes are very high. It’s important to watch how a film like Food Inc. impacts our culture–and how those who have the most to lose are fighting hard to maintain the status quo.

entry.title: A Serious Post about an Irreverent Josh Groban
entry.content:
Josh Groban is a tenor vocalist. The folks on his fan site call him a “classical crossover tenor vocalist.” In marketing-speak Crossover is a funny word. I associate it with “Crossover SUVs” that are really SUV’s without the guilt. Is that what’s going on here? Is Josh Groban just André Bocelli or worse, Il Divo, in hipster clothing? Or does Crossover mean something more?

Last week, when Josh Groban sang Kayne West tweets on Jimmy Kimmel Live, he changed the game. Well, he’s been making a name for himself for a while. Remember when he was “caught” in line for Snoop Dogg’s pot brownies on the AMA’s? Or when he sang the praises of Jimmy F(&king Ben Affleck?

Brands were traditionally thought of as having  a consistent set of personality traits. Banks, insurance companies, scotch, Mercedes would all be considered to have “serious” brand attributes, and any divergence from this into the realm of silly or irreverent would considered be damaging to the brand. Tenors would also be considered to have “serious” brand personalities.

It’s interesting to see this old brand thinking to be challenged through Groban’s antics.

The idea of brand personality is changing, and with it the whole notion of who your communities of interest are. Brands, celebrities, businesses are no longer static entities. Imagine if your “serious” friend was always serious. Serious at a party. Serious during sex. Serious at the park with his kids. And more and more brands are functioning like people. They are multi-dimensional, and people are cool with that.

By extension, communities of interest aren’t static either. So, you might think that only a certain type of person would like a tenor vocalist like Groban. And maybe that person would look like my mom. But, it turns out, that’s not the whole story. In a recent Billboard magazine interview, Groban said:

“It’s easy to generalize,” he says. “But I’d love to take people through my concert audience and point out all the different types of people who are there. I think at the start of my career my audience was older and more female, and that image has stuck around for the rest of the time. But what I think happened is these women brought their husbands and their sons and their daughters, and everybody had a great time, and now it runs the gamut.”

Check out the comments about Groban’s take on Kayne on the notably lewd website D-Listed, where in addition to the usual disses, people make comments like:

Josh Groban is so fucking cute. His awesome levels just shot up like 50 more points for me.

Maybe “awesome levels” are the new cred. Being irreverent is one of those things that allows you to seem accessible, funny, interesting……human. So you’re not just “the amazing voice,” you’re the* guy* with the amazing voice. That’s very different.

Back to the cocktail party scenario, there’s nothing more endearing than when a person surprises you. It happens to me all the time. I know someone as “edgy” and they turn out to be really sweet. Or, I think of someone as an intellectual, but I love them so much more when they make me howl with laughter at a party. Consistency is boring. Surprises are memorable.

So, how are you working to surprise people? How would exposing another side of yourself make you more accessible? Or, is accessibility sometimes a bad idea?

entry.title: How “Grown Up” Is Your Brand?
entry.content:
I just turned Forty. To acknowledge the event I wanted my husband to buy me a “bauble”–a keepsake to mark the event. I ended up with a bold choice–what those in the know might call a  “statement ring” from a great Queen Street boutique called Love of Mine. I must tell you, I love the ring. I just love it.

I’m not telling you this to brag (it was actually a relatively inexpensive purchase if you must know.) I’m telling you this because buying this ring made me think about another significant “bauble” –my engagement ring.

I never* loved* my engagement ring. I think it’s because when we bought it (8 long years ago), I wasn’t entirely sure who I was. I diverged from the obvious Tiffany diamond solitaire kind of ring, but truth be told, the ring I selected in the same general universe of other engagement rings.

Brands struggle with maturity issues all the time. I am going to go out on a limb and proclaim that you can determine a brand’s maturity level by considering how confident they are in their individuality and how they feel compelled to express it.<!--more-->

Brands that want to be different, but still use convention as a benchmark are what I call “thinking like a 30 year old.” As the engagement ring story indicates, at  30 I wanted to be my own woman, but I wasn’t sure how. As a result, I clung to certain stereotypes about how it was “supposed to be.” I may have accessorized conventionality, but I wasn’t ready to divert from the course.

I contend that brands that behave like 40 year olds are the ones that have the greatest staying power. Consider Volkswagon’s Think Small campaign from the 1950′s.  When everyone else was thinking big Volkswagon was willing to think small.  I would put the original Absolut Vodka ads in this camp–but I’d argue that they seem to be growing less mature, not more.

There’s a difference between being confident and smart and being audacious just for the sake of being audacious. That type of approach is what I would consider the 20 year old approach–something very common in beer advertising and more recently in Old Spice Ads where using sex, irony, etc. is a tactic that gets attention, but to what end?

To me, the Old Spice ads are like 20 year olds who need to be just a bit too noisy to prove they “don’t give a shit?” Ok, gotcha, you don’t give a shit. Now please move away, I can’t hear myself think.

I think the best, recent example of  a 2o year old brand is the Spence Diamonds campaign polluting bus shelters all across the GTA. I’ll save that rant for another blog post (and it’s coming up–I promise you), but needless to say, they make a loud statement, but it’s one I just don’t get.

So, now that I’m 40, I feel confident saying that the best brands behave like 40 year olds. Here’s some examples of  how they do it:

  • They don’t need to be LOUD to say something. They can say it quietly–and still be funny, intelligent, etc.
  • They are not original in order to buck tradition, they are original because it’s in their DNA.  In fact, they’re not even thinking about tradition. They don’t need to. They’re just doing what feels right and it pays dividends.

I’ve named a few, but I’m curious what brands you think qualify as  40 year old brands? What’s a 50, 60, 70 year old brand. I’d love to hear your opinion.

Update: Just saw that Sociological Images got ahold of the Spence Diamonds ad and had a few choice words for their approach to single-dom. Check out their blog post here http://thesocietypages.org/socimages/2010/12/09/stigmatizing-single-people/

entry.title: Getting to Know Movember
entry.content:
You never know where a blog post will lead you. And that’s part of the fun.

This blog post was inspired by a readers comment that raised a question prompting me to do a bit of digging.

Someone calling themselves *No Mo Here *posted the following comment on the We’re Getting Behind Movember blog post. The writer commented:

“Raising funds for Prostate Cancer Canada is positive and Movember is a great idea but, 15% of donations for Movember goes directly into the pocket of the Movember founder. It’s a little secret that this campaign doesn’t want you to know. Not all funds goes to fighting Prostate Cancer. Booo.”

No Mo Here *raised an interesting issue. Who exactly is *this mystical organization called Movember Canada? And how do they make a living? On this, the last day of Movember, I thought I’d help elucidate and clear the air.

It’s not entirely surprising that someone like No Mo *posted his/her comment. The truth is, I was also confused about who was behind Movember and its relationship to Prostate Cancer in general, and Prostate Cancer Canada in particular. While I’m a big fan of Movember, I would say that “Movember the social movement”* (men donning ‘staches for Prostate Cancer)  is well executed, but “Movember the organization” not well articulated or understood.

So, I called Jesse Hayman, Campaign Coordinator for Movember Canada to get a better understanding of these Movember folks, and here’s what I found out:

  1. *Movember is non-profit: *In Canada, Movember is a non profit organization but they don’t have charitable status. That means they can raise money but they can’t issue tax receipts. Prostate Cancer Canada issues tax receipts on their behalf. As a non profit, they each make salaries, but no money is going into anyone’s pocket–not even the founder’s.
  2. *They’re friendly: *Movember Canada’s offices are within Prostate Cancer Canada’s offices. They are separate organizations, but they sit together, and play nicely together. They are friends. Aw.
  3. *They’re in the awareness business: *Movember is a public education engine. They deliver awareness and generate funds. They don’t deliver services to folks dealing with Prostate Cancer. That’s Prostate Cancer Canada’s job. And PCC does a very good job of delivering services  through research, support, education and more. That’s why Movember Canada directs all funds to them.
  4. They’re a lean, mean awareness machine. They employ 3 staff full time in Canada. The rest of the work and outreach is done by volunteers across the country
  5. *They have costs: *The 15% raised by Movember Canada does not go into the founder’s pocket. Rather 15% of the money raised through Movember goes to pay for staff, infrastructure, materials, etc. to run a rockingly good organization moving the needle on a crucial health issue. According to Charity Navigator, organizations that spend 33.3% or less on expenses to raise money are doing their jobs just fine, thank you. Movember Canada is well within this range. But, they say they’re always trying to lower their administrative costs.
  6. They do alot of good: Last year Movember Canada raised $7.8 million for Prostate Cancer. This year, they’re headed toward the $20 million dollar mark. I’d say that’s pretty super-fantastic. If you ran a business that grossed $20 million on netted $17 million, you’d feel pretty darned good about yourself. Let’s give Movember Canada a round of applause puhlease!
  7. *They could do better: *Movember Canada and Movember in general could do a better job of positioning themselves within this very important movement. That would help others trust their motivations and understand their strong connection to the issue of Prostate Cancer, and Prostate Cancer Canada. If that helps people part with their money than all the better.

So there you go *No Mo Here, *maybe now that I’ve cleared things up you can rename yourself *Grow Mo Here *when Movember rolls around again.

Happy last day of Movember everyone!

entry.title: Dying to Shop: Correlating Bad Health and Cheap Stuff
entry.content:
Just started reading a fascinating book called The Emperor of All Maladies: A Biography of Cancer that traces the history of the elusive disease and its treatments. In it, the author Sidhartha Mukherjee talks about dramatic medical  developments that lead to current cancer treatments.

Mukherjee claims that the widepread purchaing of “durables” from the 1920′s onward coincided with a rapid increase in the number and kind of drugs that dramatically lengthened people’s lifespan and their sense of immortality. It’s hard to believe, but life expectancy for Americans rose from fourty-seven to sixty-eight in the first half of the 20th century.

“A young generation thus dreamed of cures–of a death free, disease free existence. Lullued by the idea of the durability of life, they threw themselves into consuming durables”

In other words, people bought Studebakers and TV’s because they suddenly felt like they were going to live forever–or at least for a long, long time. So they invested stuff that would be around too.

So what does it say about our current state of mind that we live in a disposable culture? Whenever I find myself in a ‘big box’ store, I’m stunned by the sheer quantity of junk people are willing to pay hard earned money for. Of course that effect is amplified during holiday season.

Last week, my friend Kelly Drennan, founder of Fashion Takes Action posted this article on her Facebook page that that talks about how cheap fashionable clothes are these days. Cheapness in the price of clothes is of course accompanied by low quality. But no one seems to mind. The article quotes one woman’s reaction to her cheap summer dresses falling apart after only one season of wear:

“Usually for those kinds of things I don’t even consider really whether or not I’ll have them around for next summer,” she says. “If I do, great. If not, because they were so cheap it almost doesn’t really matter.”

Is it a coincidence that our culture of consumption is accompanied by a health crisis? Diabetes, cancer, obesity, etc. are all on the rise and we’re buying more and more disposable crap. Is our sense of mortality causing us to become a more disposable culture?

We deliberately turn a blind eye to the fact that all this stuff is literally killing us and the planet–so perhaps it’s a vicious cycle. More stuff=bad health=more stuff. And on and on and on.

Have a look at The Story of Stuff for a quick Coles Notes version of how the materials economy works:

Last week, I came across an article called New Relationships with our Stuff that posits a new movement is afoot. Websites like Neighbourgoods and Snapgoods allow people to borrow, rent and sell  things they they already have rather than getting them new from a store. The local, artisinal and craft movements are also evidence of this shift.

Does it mean we’re feeling more immortal? Is this an effort to get back to a time when things were more solid and predictable rather than temporal and fleeting? Are we seeking better health? Better lives? Less stuff?

There’s a conference in San Fransisco in January where these issues will be the central focus of discussion. It’s called Compostmodern, and I’m thinking about checking it out. Anyone want to come?
